snippet.title: LearnNext Class 7 English Writing Skills l Short Writing Skills | Message Writing
snippet.description:
A message is the method of conveying information in a precise and clear manner.

How to write a message effectively:

Use appropriate language, style and format.
It can be written both in a formal and informal tone.
Be clear, brief and direct


General Instructions for message writing:

A message does not need an address.
The message must be put in a box.
The key points are to be very brief and precise

snippet.title: Respiration in Organisms - Science - Class 7
snippet.description:
The cells in our body perform functions like growth, excretion, reproduction, etc. A cell needs energy to perform these functions. The food we take in is converted into glucose by the digestive system.
The cells of living organisms require a constant supply of oxygen to release energy. This is done by a process called breathing.  Breathing involves two steps - one inhalation and one exhalation. The breath rate of human beings is 15 -- 18 breaths a minute.
Air passes through the tiny hair in the nasal cavity, and then through the pharynx, larynx and windpipe before reaching the lungs.  The hairs in the nasal cavity prevent the entry of dust particles and pollen. The mucous lining is present from the nasal cavity to the lungs. Read More at https://learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VII-Science-Breathing.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Electric Current and its Effects - Electric Components - Science - Class 7
snippet.description:
In the 19th century, James Joule studied a property, which says that "when an electric current flows through the filament of a bulb, it generates heat, and so the bulb becomes hot". This property is named the heating effect of electric current.
When electric current flows through a wire wound around an iron bar, the bar behaves like a magnet. This magnet is called an electromagnet.
An electromagnet is formed due to the magnetic effect of electric current. This magnetic effect of electric current was discovered by Hans Christian Oersted. Once, while preparing for a lecture, he noticed that there was a deflection in the needle of a magnetic compass kept near a wire that was connected to a battery. This deflection occurred every time the battery was switched on and off. He realised that a magnetic field is created around a current-carrying wire in a circuit. Read More at https://learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VII-Science-The-Magnetic-Effect-of-Electric-Current.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Rational Numbers - Introduction to Rational Numbers - Maths - Class 7
snippet.description:
All numbers, including whole numbers, integers, fractions and decimal numbers, can be written in the numerator-denominator form.  A rational number is a number that can be written in the form p/q, where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0...  The denominator of a rational number can never be zero.  A rational number is positive if its numerator and denominator are both either positive integers or negative integers. If either the numerator or the denominator of a rational number is a negative integer, then the rational number is called a negative rational number.  Read More at https://learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VII-Maths-Introduction-to-Rational-Numbers.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Perimeter and Area- Plane figures - Maths - Class 7
snippet.description:
Triangle:
A triangle is a polygon with three vertices, and three sides or edges that are line segments. A triangle with vertices A, B, and C is denoted as ABC
Circle:
A circle is defined as a collection of points on a plane that are at an equal distance from a
fixed point on the plane.  The fixed point is called the centre of the circle. Read more at https://learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VII-Maths-Circles.htm

snippet.title: The Living Organisms And Their Surroundings -- Habitat and Adaptation - Class 7
snippet.description:
Livings things exist in most places. Life exists even in open volcanoes. The term habitat refers to the surroundings where organisms live. Every habitat is home for a certain living creature. Habitat includes both living and non-living components. Plants and animals have different features that help them to survive in their own habitat. Habitat can be terrestrial or aquatic.

Terrestrial habitat refers to the land where all plants and animals survive. It includes deserts, forests and grasslands, as well as coastal and mountain regions. For example, camels and cactus plants live in deserts only. Read more at https://www.learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VI-Science-Habitat-Adaptation.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Motion And Measurement of Distances - Transportation and Distances - Class 7
snippet.description:
Before the invention of the wheel, the only means of transportation was walking. For transporting goods, people used animals like donkeys, horses, mules, elephants, oxen, sled dogs, and even bison. Boats were also used as a means of transportation on water. The earliest boats were simple logs of wood with a hollow cavity.

The oldest wheel was discovered in Mesopotamia, and is believed to be over 5,500 years old. Fixed wheels for carts were invented around 3500 BC, according to some historians. After the invention of the wheel, man started using animals to pull vehicles that moved on wheels, and thus, bullock carts and chariots came into existence. Till the 19th century, most forms of transport used only animals. Read More at https://www.learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VI-Science-Transportation-and-Distances.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 7 | Maths | Comparing Quantities | Conversions
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Maths | Comparing Quantities | Conversions

In this module, you will learn how to convert decimal numbers into a percentages and vice-versa.

Let’s start with converting the number point zero seven to a percentage.
To convert from decimal to percentage, we just need to multiply the decimal by hundred percent. 
Here, we will multiply zero point zero seven with hundred percent to get seven percent.
The easiest way convert a decimal number into percentage is to move the decimal point two places to the right and add a percent sign.
So in point six five, we move the decimal point two places to the right.
We get sixty-five point zero which is equal to sixty-five.
Adding the percentage sign gives us sixty-five percent.
Narrator: Similarly, take a look at decimal number one point five.
Here we only have one place after the decimal point.
We know that many zeros can be placed after point five without changing its value. So how do we move the decimal point by two places?
We simply move the decimal point two places to the right by placing a decimal point after one zero to get one hundred and fifty points zero which is equal to one hundred and fifty and place a percent sign at the end.
Narrator: Another way of converting a decimal number zero point four to percentage is by converting the decimal to a fraction then multiplying it by hundred percent.
We get forty percent.

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 7 | Maths | Integer | Operations on Integer
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Maths | Integer | Operations on Integer

In this module, you will learn how to divide integers.
Let the distance covered by the submarine below the sea level be 1000 metres in hundred minutes
So, the velocity or speed of the submarine is minus ten metres per minute.
This is obtained by dividing minus thousand by hundred.
Here, did you notice the division of integers? 
Take a look at the example given here. 
You can see that minus three times minus five gives us fifteen. And, fifteen divided by minus three gives minus five.
So, the division of a positive integer by a negative integer results in a negative integer.
Now consider another example.
Here again, the division of a negative integer by a positive integer results in a negative integer.
In both these cases, the two integers are divided as whole numbers and a minus sign is placed before the quotient or the resultant.
So, in general, for any two positive integers p and q, p divided by minus q, is equal to minus p divided by q, 
Now, observe the example of a negative integer getting divided by another negative integer.

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 7 | Maths | Visualizing Solid Shapes | Introduction to Solid Shapes
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Maths | Visualizing Solid Shapes | Introduction to Solid Shapes

In this module, you will learn about three-dimensional shapes and the concept of nets. 
Figures such as squares, rectangles, triangles and circles are called two-dimensional figures. 
These figures have only two dimensions, length, and breadth. 
Two-dimensional figures can be combined to form three dimensional shapes. 
For example, six squares can be combined to form a cube. 
Likewise, three parallelograms and two triangles can be combined to form a triangular prism. 
Some of the three-dimensional shapes we encounter in our daily life are balls, ice cream cones, food tins and dice. 
Three-dimensional shapes as the name suggests will have three dimensions, length, breadth and height. 

Sometimes the height is also called as depth. 
For any solid shape, the surface may be curved or flat or a combination of two. 
For a cube, the surfaces are all flat.
The flat surface of a three-dimensional shape is called a face.

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

snippet.title: Class 7 | Science | Light | Images Formed by Lens
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Science | Light | Images Formed by Lens

In this module you will learn about different types of lenses and the characteristics of images formed by convex lenses
Have you ever seen through a peephole?
Images seen through a peephole are different from those seen through a normal glass.
Do you know what kind of lens is that?
It’s a concave lens.
This lens in our peephole makes objects appear smaller!
Have you ever seen a person repairing a watch?  How does he manage to locate and fix such tiny parts? 
See the eyepiece? It has a lens that magnifies the images of the parts of a watch.
Take a look at this magnifying glass.

The watch repairer uses a convex lens. This lens makes objects placed close to it appear larger, when seen through it. 

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 7 | Science | Nutrition in Plants
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Science | Nutrition in Plants

In this module, you will learn about autotrophic nutrition in plants.

Where do we get our nutrients from?

We get our nutrients from, vegetables, fruits or meat. Most of the animals that we consume as meat depends on plants for their nourishment.
We are all directly or indirectly dependent on plants for our nutrition. 
Plants can be divided into autotrophs and heterotrophs based on their mode of nutrition. Autotrophs include most of the plants, algae and a few bacteria. Heterotrophs include parasites,
saprotrophs and symbionts.

What are autotrophs?

The first mode consists of autotrophs or plants that prepare their own food.Most green plants fall under this group. Where do plants obtain their nutrients from?

Plants collect simple substances like water 

To watch more Class 7 Science videos.

Visit: https://www.learnnext.com/CBSE/Class-7/Science/Biology/Nutrition-in-Plants/Nutrients-in-Plants/L-2628.htm#container

snippet.title: Class 7 | Science | Reproduction in Plants | Asexual Reproduction
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Science | Reproduction in Plants | Asexual Reproduction

In this module, you will learn about reproduction in plants.
Do plants grow without seeds?
New plants can be grown even without the seeds.
The process of producing young ones is called reproduction.  
The young one looks similar to the parent plant.
What are the different ways in which plants produce their offspring?
There are several ways by which plants produce their offspring (young ones). 
These are mainly divided into two types – sexual and asexual.
The sexual mode of reproduction involves the fusion of the male and the female gametes ...
...to form seeds that eventually develop into a new plant. The seeds are formed inside the fruit.
In an asexual mode of reproduction, a new plant is grown from any part of the plant other than the seeds. 

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 7 | Science | Soil | Soil Profile
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Science | Soil | Soil Profile


In this module, you will learn about soil profile.  

Agriculture is the most important use of soil.
Agriculture provides all of us with food to eat, fibre for our clothes and material for making houses. Without soil, agriculture is not possible. Therefore, soil is a natural resource that is essential for life.
Soil has several other uses. It’s used in gardens, as well as in construction and pottery. 
 Soil is formed when rocks are broken down by the action of wind, water and climate. This process is called weathering. 

That is why the characteristic features of any soil depend upon the rocks from which it has been formed and the kind of plants that grow in it.

snippet.title: Class 7 | Maths | Comparing Quantities | Percentages
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Maths | Comparing Quantities | Percentages

In this module, you will learn how to calculate the percentage of a given number.
Percent is derived from the latin word ‘ percentum’. 
Per centum is made of two words per and centum.
The meaning of cent is hundred.
So, percent literally means per hundred or every hundred.
Percent is denoted by this sign.
The concept of percentage can be explained using the example of air composition.Look carefully.  Air is made up of many gases. This image assumes that all the gases of the atmosphere if combined together, form a hundred parts.
If the total air composition is hundred, then seventy-eight parts out of hundred parts or seventy-eight percent of the total air composition is formed by nitrogen.

snippet.title: Class 7 | Maths | Integer | Properties of Integer
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Maths | Integer | Properties of Integer

In this module, you will learn about the associative property of integers under addition.
Take a look at this problem. Let’s try and prove this property with the help of the number line.
First, we represent the sum on the number line.
Now we represent the second sum on the number line to check the final result. 
As you can see, the result in both the cases is the same - that is minus nine.
The example shows us that we can either add "minus three and minus two" together and then add that sum to minus four to get the final answer, 
or we can add "minus four and minus three" together first and then add that sum to minus two to get the final answer. 
The answer will be the same, no matter which way we do it.
This shows that addition is associative for integers.
Hence, 
for any integers a, b and c, we have
a + (b + c) = (a + b) + c.

snippet.title: Class 7 | Maths | Visualizing Solid Shapes | Viewing Different Sections of Solids
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Maths | Visualizing Solid Shapes | Viewing Different Sections of Solids

In this module, you will learn how to draw oblique and isometric sketches of solid shapes on a flat surface.
Two-dimensional figures can be drawn in such a way that they resemble three-dimensional shapes. 
For example, here is a solid cuboid. We can draw a figure resembling this cuboid on a flat surface like a paper.  
When completed, the two-dimensional figure resembles a solid shaped cuboid. 
These figures may be drawn either as an oblique sketch or an isometric sketch. 
For the oblique sketch, we will need a paper with squares printed on it. 
First we draw two rectangles as shown. 
Each rectangle has four vertices. We will join each vertex of one rectangle with the corresponding vertex of the other rectangle.
Now, the completed sketch looks like a cuboid.

snippet.title: Class 7 | Science | Light | Reflection of Light
snippet.description:
Class 7 | Science | Light | Reflection of Light

In this module, you will be able to demonstrate that the path of light is always a straight line and to explain the reflection of light from plane mirrors.
Do you know how an umbrella helps you to protect against the hot sunlight on a sunny day?

It blocks the sun’s rays from reaching us.

That is because light can’t bend around objects. Light always travels in a straight line.

The direction of light can only be changed through reflection.
Let’s see some common examples that prove that light travels in straight lines.
Did you notice the path of light when we switched on a torch? 

The light goes in a straight path to an incident on the wall. It does not bend anywhere.
At times, we see how the sun’s rays are filtered through the clouds. 

We can clearly see the light rays in straight lines here.
